intro: Silene parishii, commonly known as the Parish's catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its delicate, pinkish-white flowers and hairy, glandular leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as meadows and rocky soils. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, which includes other flowering plants with showy blooms. Due to its limited range and habitat specificity, Silene parishii is considered a rare and endangered species.
